title: 109_s831
content: The Act may be cited as the "Health Workforce Advisory Commission Act of 2005" and establishes the Health Workforce Advisory Commission. The Health Workforce Advisory Commission, established by the Comptroller General, consists of 18 appointed members with expertise in health care workforce issues. The Health Workforce Advisory Commission, established by the Comptroller General, consists of 18 appointed members with expertise in health care workforce issues, including economics, public health policy, and healthcare systems financing. Members are geographically representative of the United States, include a representative from the Public Health Service, and represent various healthcare professions. The Health Workforce Advisory Commission, established by the Comptroller General, consists of 18 appointed members with expertise in health care workforce issues. Members include health care providers from rural areas and individuals not primarily involved in health professions education. Terms of service are for 3 years with staggered appointments for initial members. Vacancies are filled promptly. The Health Workforce Advisory Commission, established by the Comptroller General, consists of 18 appointed members with expertise in health care workforce issues. Members include health care providers from rural areas and individuals not primarily involved in health professions education. Terms of service are for 3 years with staggered appointments for initial members. Vacancies are filled promptly. A vacancy on the Commission that occurs before the expiration of the term for which the member's predecessor was appointed shall be appointed only for the remainder of that term. The Comptroller General designates a member to serve as the Chairperson and Vice Chairperson of the Commission, with the member serving in that role for their term. The Health Workforce Advisory Commission, established by the Comptroller General, consists of 18 appointed members with expertise in health care workforce issues. Vacancies in the Chairpersonship or Vice Chairpersonship are filled promptly by the Comptroller General designating another member to serve for the remainder of the vacant member's term. The Commission reviews health workforce policies implemented under various acts and departments, and analyzes to make recommendations for improvement. The Health Workforce Advisory Commission, established by the Comptroller General, analyzes and makes recommendations to improve methods for measuring and monitoring the health workforce, reviewing policies' impact on healthcare services, and recommending Federal incentives for promoting education of health professionals in the US. They also analyze and recommend appropriate supply and distribution of physicians, nurses, and other health professionals. The Health Workforce Advisory Commission analyzes the role of internationally trained health professionals, diversity in the health workforce, and conducts public meetings to discuss policy issues and formulate recommendations for Congress and the Secretary of Health and Human Services. They consider research, expert presentations, and input from interested parties during these meetings. The Health Workforce Advisory Commission makes recommendations to Congress on health workforce policy issues, submits reports annually to Congress, and periodically reports on specific high importance issues. They also carry out activities determined appropriate by the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The Health Workforce Advisory Commission reviews reports related to health workforce policy submitted by the Secretary to Congress and provides written comments and recommendations to the appropriate committees of Congress within 6 months. The Commission also consults periodically with Congress committees on agenda and additional reviews. The Health Workforce Advisory Commission submits reports to Congress on health workforce policy and provides recommendations. The Commission may conduct additional reviews and submit reports as requested. Reports are made available to the public, and the Commission's powers are subject to review by the Comptroller General. The Commission, as determined by the Comptroller General, has the authority to employ personnel, seek assistance from federal departments, enter contracts, make payments, and provide transportation for personnel serving without compensation. The Commission, as authorized by the Comptroller General, can employ personnel, seek assistance from federal departments, enter contracts, make payments, and provide transportation for uncompensated personnel. The Commission has unrestricted access to GAO records and can obtain necessary information from US departments and agencies as agreed upon. The Commission, chaired by the head of the department or agency involved, utilizes existing information, conducts original research, allows interested parties to submit information, and carries out other appropriate activities as determined by the Commission. Administrative provisions allow the Commission to employ personnel, seek assistance, enter contracts, make payments, and access necessary information from US departments and agencies. The Commission, chaired by the head of the department or agency involved, utilizes existing information, conducts original research, allows interested parties to submit information, and carries out other appropriate activities as determined by the Commission. Administrative provisions include compensation for members, meeting arrangements, appointment of an interim Executive Director, and establishment of a system for ethical disclosure by members. The Commission, chaired by the head of the department or agency involved, conducts audits and submits funding requests separately from the Comptroller General. $6,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2006, with additional appropriations as needed. 80% of the funds are available from the Federal Hospital Insurance. The Federal Hospital Insurance Trust Fund provides funding under section 1817 of the Social Security Act. 20 percent of the appropriation is allocated for carrying out title XIX of the Act. The term "appropriate committees of Congress" refers to specific committees in the Senate and House of Representatives.
